channel.title: Ubuntu 10.04 vs. Puppy 4.2
channel.description:
I have a delema, i currently have Ubuntu on my harddrive, but after the troubles on connecting to wireless internet, I decided to look at other distributions of Linux. I want to know, do you think i should go ahead and wipe out Ubuntu and just change to Puppy 4.2, or Stay with it.
My pro's and con's of just the little while ive had both.
Ubuntu: Pro - Nice GUI, (nothing else to decide on yet -.- (is on my harddrive atm) Con - Cant even get it to connect to something via wireless, but it does find hotspots?
Puppy 4.2: Pro - Ran this build-in program, and it reconised my Belkin-N card immediately (also currently using via CD) Con - Not a very good GUI
I just want to know your opinions, since i know very little about either.

item.title: Ubuntu 10.04 vs. Puppy 4.2
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:2, topic:342593”]Ubuntu is really easy to use. If you’re not entirely comfortable with a linux environment it’s perfect! As someone mentioned before you should just use ndiswrapper to wrap the windows driver which i’m sure you’ll be able to find.

Puppy linux is great to boot in a live enviroment and I use it if I ever need need a live cd however everything else sucks…

I personally use arch linux, running xfce4 and I use Wicd to connect to wireless networks. I have no problems using it however if you have difficulties using ubuntu, you will probably find it even harder to use my setup.[/quote]

Its not the Ubuntu itself i have difficulties with, its just getting it to connect to the hotspots it is able to find. I will download ndiswrapper, and see if i can get it to do anything with that. I’ll let you know if it works.

Didn’t get any further using ndiswrapper. I actually got an error saying “driver already installed” so im guessing i never needed it.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu 10.04 vs. Puppy 4.2
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Ubuntu is really easy to use. If you’re not entirely comfortable with a linux environment it’s perfect! As someone mentioned before you should just use ndiswrapper to wrap the windows driver which i’m sure you’ll be able to find.

Puppy linux is great to boot in a live enviroment and I use it if I ever need need a live cd however everything else sucks…

I personally use arch linux, running xfce4 and I use Wicd to connect to wireless networks. I have no problems using it however if you have difficulties using ubuntu, you will probably find it even harder to use my setup.

Read full topic
